content: The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who employ low-wage employees based on a percentage of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" refers to those required to make tax deposits under chapters 21 and 24 of the Internal Revenue Code. The term "applicable employer" for the Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017 refers to employers required to make tax deposits under chapters 21 and 24 of the Internal Revenue Code for more than 180 days in the preceding calendar year. The term "applicable employer" for the Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017 excludes Federal or governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with exceptions. The Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017 excludes Federal or governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with exceptions regarding the definition of a low-wage employee. The amendments will be effective for calendar years starting after the enactment date of the Act.
